fact: Globally, only about 22 % of electronic waste is formally recycled, significantly below the UN’s target of 50 % by 2030, underscoring a massive opportunity to recover valuable materials and reduce environmental harm.

Recycling just one ton of aluminum saves approximately 14,000 kWh of energy—about 95 % less than producing new aluminum from ore—highlighting the massive energy potential from recovering metal in e-waste.

The average lifecycle carbon footprint of a laptop ranges from 200 to 300 kg CO₂e, with production contributing over 60 % of emissions. Extending device lifespan or recycling significantly helps reduce this burden.

Purchasing a refurbished laptop rather than a new one can avoid around 254 kg CO₂e in emissions, according to industry analyses, making refurbishing one of the easiest ways to shrink personal digital carbon footprints.
Thanks to material recovery, recycling aluminum reduces the demand for bauxite ore by up to 8 tons per ton of recycled metal, dramatically easing pressure on mining and environmental degradation.

India generated approximately 1.9 million tonnes of electronic waste in 2023, making it the third-largest e-waste producer globally and highlighting an urgent need for scalable collection and recycling infrastructure.
Over 90 % of electronic waste in India is processed by the informal sector, where recycling is unregulated and hazardous. This creates serious risks of toxin exposure and environmental pollution.

India’s formal e-waste recycling rate is estimated at just 20 %, far below its generation rate. Vast quantities of end-of-life electronics are still discarded improperly, posing growing health and environmental threats.

Brand take-back initiatives launched in India have shown success in responsibly collecting and recycling e-waste. These programs recover valuable materials while reducing hazardous informal practices.

Just like globally, recycling electronics in India—especially aluminum-rich items—can save up to 95 % of the energy compared to producing virgin metal. Scaling this can help India’s energy strategy sustainably.
